text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

This section contains information on Non-Filer Program procedures for administrative matters and provides a reference for common issues and related items that might be found on tax returns. Throughout this revision there are references to other IRMs which may contain related information needed when working cases.
4.19.17.5.2.4 - Updated reference to 5.18.1.8.2.3.20 due to IRM 5 revision
4.19.17.7.2 - Updated reference to 25.25.10, Frivolous Return Program based on FRP realignment and IRM renumbering
4.19.17.7.8 - Updated reference to IRM 4.19.13.25, General Case Development and Resolution, Campus Identity Theft based on IRM revision; removed program speciﬁc guidance as it no longer
ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
(1) This material supersedes IRM 4.19.17, dated 10/0113/2015.
This IRM is intended for the use of the SB/SE Campus Examination

) The Non-Filer program, also known as SFR (Substitute for Return), and its automated version, Automated Substitute For Return (ASFR) were Program to contact taxpayers who have not ﬁled tax returns voluntarily and for whom income information is available to substantiate a signiﬁcant income tax (
) Internal Revenue Code Section (IRC)
authorizes the Service to send notice of deﬁciency when a taxpayer appears to have a ﬁling requirement does not comply by voluntarily ﬁling a tax return. (
) The Service has the authority to prepare returns for any person who fails to submit a return required by Internal Revenue law or regulation at the time

(b) scribed, or makes (willfully or otherwise), a false, or fraudulent return. The return is prepared from the personal knowledge of the Service’s employee from information which can be obtained through testimony or otherwise. (

(b) return is not treated as a return ﬁled by the taxpayer. example be aware of the following: a. The amount shown as tax on an IRC §

(b) pertains to individual income tax returns. Such returns may automatically generated by the Campus or manually prepared with reports proposed tax adjustments. (

(b) return to apply the Failure to Pay Penalty. (

) Whenever the examiner revises a report of proposed adjustments that increases the total tax liability of the taxpayer (without regard to whether or the revised report is reissued to the taxpayer), a re-certiﬁcation is required another Form
dated on (or after) the same day as the revised report. (

for each year and attach each one to a photocopy of the report for each year. Note: Form
is an internal use only form and should not be sent to taxpayer(s). (
) The National Non-Filer Strategy is directly aligned with the Service’s effort identify non-compliant taxpayers and design methods to encourage their Strategy pliance. (

) The Campus Examination Operations participate in the Non-Filer Strategy either: • Directly under the guidelines in the IRM or • By providing support for Area Offices (AO)in their Non-Filer Program efforts. (

) Headquarters Examination establishes the priority of cases to be selected based on the availability of cases identiﬁed through the Collection Inventory Inventory & and other Compliance Service initiatives for investigation by Examination. (

) Headquarters Examination Workload Selection performs periodic reviews of inventory selected, addresses inventory selection concerns and improves selection by modifying selection criteria or suggests new initiatives. (
) The examination begins when a compliance check reveals ﬁling with potential for tax assessment. Processing (

) In most cases the Non-ﬁler case is worked through ACE processing and will move systemically through the Correspondence Exam process without spondence Examination Technician intervention unless a return or reply is received from the taxpayer.

Whenever the examiner revises a report of proposed adjustments that increases the total tax liability of the taxpayer (without regard to whether or not the revised report is reissued to the taxpayer), a re-certiﬁcation is required on another Form 13496 dated on (or after) the same day as the revised report.
Form 13496 is an internal use only form and should not be sent to the taxpayer(s).

Taxpayer has U/R NEC of $ amount. Taxpayer also has LUQ contributions and EBE. Update entity for Joint ﬁling. per return. Issue Letter 692. RSED expired; hold excess credits until ﬁnal closing.

Schedule C AO issues, refer to Classiﬁcation. Received back from Classiﬁcation, return accepted as ﬁled. Update entity for Joint ﬁling. Close case DCXX. RSED expired credits to Excess Collection.

All income reported. Schedule C for EITC purposes refer to Classiﬁcation. Received back from Classiﬁcation, accept as ﬁled, and close using appropriate DC.
4.19.17.3.8 (01-05-2010) Partial Assessments
a SFR has posted and the examination is continuing or the taxpayer is appealing the reasonable cause determination. (
) Ensure the return has been validated, prior to making a partial assessment the return. (
) DO NOT resolve credit balances on partial assessments until ﬁnal case closure. (
) Update ﬁling status and name line, if applicable, and Assessment Statute ration Date (ASED) as appropriate. (
) Do not update the activity code until after the examination is completed. (
) Follow procedures in IRM
, General Case Development and and IRM
, Discretionary Programs, for subsequent contacts with the taxpayer after a partial assessment. (

) If No Reply after SNOD has already been issued and the taxpayer’s ﬁling status is Single, Head of Household, or MFS and the increase in tax does meet new deﬁciency guidelines, allow the SNOD to default on Unagreed and/or No Reply cases before making the assessment per the corrected report. (

) If the Non-Filer SNOD has already been issued and the taxpayer’s ﬁling per the secured return is Joint, a new SNOD must be issued in the Joint to allow the spouse the same deﬁciency rights the Non-Filer taxpayer prior to making the assessment per the corrected report. It is not necessary wait until the Non-Filer SNOD has expired before issuing a Joint SNOD or rescind the previous Non-Filer SNOD. (
) Several reviews are mandatory during Non-Filer case processing: a. Deﬁciencies of $
b. ACE Manual Rejects c. Closed Cases over $
d. Statutory Notices of Deﬁciency over $
4.19.17.3.8.1 (10-01-2015) Contacts After Partial Assessments

If the Non-Filer SNOD has already been issued and the taxpayer’s ﬁling status per the secured return is Joint, a new SNOD must be issued in the Joint name to allow the spouse the same deﬁciency rights the Non-Filer taxpayer received prior to making the assessment per the corrected report. The general rule is that an assessment of tax must be made within three years from the date a return is ﬁled or the due date of the return whichever is later. Generally, this means that tax must be posted or journalized to Master File within
years from the received date of the return. Additionally, the Service has three years to assess additional tax due. See IRM

, Statute of Limi- tations, for exceptions to assessing additional tax within three years from the received date or due date of a return whichever is later and for a more thorough explanation of the ASED, and the conditions that extend the ASED.

do not the running of the ASED. Therefore, the ASED must be set when processing delinquent returns. (

, Joint Return After Separate Return, for limitations to processing separate to joint returns. (
) Non-Filer delinquent returns that are tax increases must be posted to Master File within three years of the received date. If a return is received with an ASED within
days, see IRM
, After Hours and Imminent ments. (

) Penalties to be considered on secured delinquent returns and IRC §
(a) returns are: a. Failure to File Penalty IRC §

) The initial request for relief may occur either during or after an examination. (
) When the tax liability has been resolved, the FTF and FTP penalties are applied unless the taxpayer has provided an explanation and documentation for Reasonable Cause (RC). (
) Refer to IRM
, Criteria for Relief from Penalties, as a resource guide for the non-assertion of penalties due to RC. (
) If the taxpayer is entitled to penalty relief, document work papers that RC considered, and how RC was established. (

) If the taxpayer is not entitled to penalty relief, document work papers that RC was considered and why RC does not apply and what penalties are to be assessed when the case is forwarded to AIMS as both partial and ﬁnal ments. Also include the date to start the FTP penalty if the FTP penalty applies. Note: Compute the FTP penalty on both delinquent returns and IRC Sec.
(a) returns from the due date of the return. (

(1) When responding to telephone inquiries, disclose no tax return information until reasonably certain the person making the inquiry is the taxpayer or his/her au- and thorized representative. For complete disclosure information, see IRM 21.1.3.2, General Disclosure Guidelines. (2) During the telephone contact: and telephone inquiries on Non-ﬁler cases without a return will often ask general questions such as how to secure prior year forms, requests for extension, or explain why the taxpayer is not required to ﬁle. The table below provides a list of the most common taxpayer replies and guidelines on how to respond. IF THEN Taxpayer needs • Request for additional time to ﬁle prior to more time to ﬁle a SNOD will be considered on a case by return case basis dependent on the taxpayers need for the additional time. Extensions past 30 days should not be given. • If SNOD has been issued, DO NOT grant an extension. Explain the time remaining on the SNOD and that the account will be assessed per the Exam report if not received within this time. Also explain returns can be considered as reconsidera- tion but, it is to the taxpayer’s beneﬁt to ﬁle as soon as possible. See Exception below. Exception: Use professional judgment in holding a case when SNOD has expired. ) A return is not considered ﬁled for interest computation purposes until the return is received in processable form. (

) A return is in processable form if it: a. Is ﬁled on a permitted form; b. Contains the taxpayer’s name, address, and identifying number; c. Has the required signature(s); and d. Contains sufficient information (whether on the return or on required tachments) to permit the mathematical veriﬁcation of the tax liability on the return. (

) Refund Hold (RH) inventory occurs when the Service holds individual tax refunds and credit elects when a current or prior year refund return is Hold (RH) Cases and the taxpayer’s account has at least one unﬁled tax return within the ﬁve years prior to the current tax year. The refund is used to offset any balance due on the delinquent return(s). If there is no balance due, or an amount remains after offsetting, the refund is released to the taxpayer. If after initial contact, the delinquent return(s) are not ﬁled, a Statutory Notice of may be issued. Once issued, the refund can be transferred to the tax year of the proposed deﬁciency(ies). It will remain there until a return is ﬁled or the Service imposes the proposed assessment after the appropriate suspense period. (

) Refund Hold (RH) inventory occurs when the Service holds individual tax refunds and credit elects when a current or prior year refund return is and the taxpayer’s account has at least one unﬁled tax return within the years prior to the current tax year. The refund is used to offset any balance due on the delinquent return(s). If there is no balance due, or an amount remains after offsetting, the refund is released to the taxpayer. Each functional area that is assigned a RH case is responsible for monitoring its cases and ensuring disposition of the case is expeditious and timely.

IRC Section 6611(e) provides that there is no interest if an overpayment is refunded within 45 days after the due date of the return, or in the case of a late ﬁled return, within 45 days after the return is ﬁled. If, however, the refund is not made within the 45 day period, interest must be paid from the date of overpayment. Thus, it is im- perative RH cases be processed expeditiously and monitored for the most expeditious resolution possible to prevent additional cost to the Service while processing these cases.

) U.S. citizens who are self-employed must pay Self-Employment Tax on net Self-Employment earnings of $

or more. This rule applies even when the earnings are excludable from gross income (or whether a U.S. income tax return must otherwise be ﬁled). Residents of Puerto Rico who have net Self- Employment income, and do not have to ﬁle Form

SS, U.S. Self-Employment Tax Return (Including the Additional Child Tax Credit for Bona Fide Residents of Puerto Rico), to compute their Self-Employment Tax. (

) Do not waive penalties in Non-ﬁler cases without reasonable taxpayer has met the reasonable cause and good faith exception is a facts circumstances determination made on a case by case basis. The most important factor is the extent of the taxpayer’s effort to assess the proper liability. Taxpayers are required to exercise ordinary business care and prudence, i.e., taking that degree of care that a reasonable, prudent person would exercise. It is the examiner’s responsibility to solicit and evaluate the taxpayer’s explanation for the position taken with respect to an issue or with respect to late ﬁling. However, it is the taxpayer’s responsibility to support or her explanation. Regardless of the reasons advanced, the taxpayer must have exercised ordinary business care and prudence. IRM

) Do not waive penalties in Non-ﬁler cases without reasonable cause.Whether a taxpayer has met the reasonable cause and good faith exception is a facts and circumstances determination made on a case by case basis. The most important factor is the extent of the taxpayer’s effort to assess the proper tax liability. Taxpayers are required to exercise ordinary business care and prudence, i.e., taking that degree of care that a reasonable, prudent person would exercise. It is the examiner’s responsibility to solicit and evaluate the taxpayer’s explanation for the position taken with respect to an issue or with respect to late ﬁling. However, it is the taxpayer’s responsibility to support his or her explanation. Regardless of the reasons advanced, the taxpayer must have exercised ordinary business care and prudence. IRM

, Penalty Handbook, will provide assistance and should be used as a resource guide for the assertion or non-assertion of penalties and correct calculations of appropri- ate penalties in Non-ﬁler cases. Remember that the taxpayer must be given appeal rights, as per Pub
, Taxpayer Rights. (
) The taxpayer may request an abatement of penalties even after the examina- tion is closed using Form
, Claim for Refund and Request for Abatement. The taxpayer will still bear the same burden to demonstrate the reasonable cause exception is met.

) Since the proposed adjustment is based on amounts the taxpayer has to the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, generally documents submitted by taxpayer will not reduce their assessment. Include standard paragraphs and
in the explanation to the taxpayer. Ask the taxpayer to submit a of the return ﬁled with the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, if they dispute our calculation. (

) The tax was paid under the secondary taxpayer’s account. Verify the by: a. Securing a copy of the return ﬁled with the Commonwealth of Puerto to see if the income was for a secondary taxpayer. b. Viewing the secondary taxpayer’s account to insure the return was properly ﬁled. c. Close the case No Change. (

) The tax is owed by the secondary taxpayer. Verify the situation by: a. Securing a copy of the return ﬁled with the Commonwealth of Puerto to see if the income was for a secondary taxpayer. b. Close the case No Change. Note: The secondary taxpayer may have to be opened for examination. A notice must be sent to the secondary taxpayer, if the tax is not paid or the tax is self assessed. (

) There are estimated tax payments on the taxpayer’s account. Verify the situation by: a. Viewing the taxpayer’s account to insure the payments were made. b. Recalculate the penalties and issue a revised examination report. (

) The taxpayer submitted a return, which was processed after the “Substitute Return” posted. Verify the situation by: a. Comparing the income reported and the tax self-assessed with the nation report. b. Securing a copy of the return ﬁled to reconcile any differences between the two. c. Revise the examination report and continue our examination, if the er’s self-assessment fails to satisfy the examination issue. d. If we are accepting the taxpayer’s return, close the case No Change. ) Part or all of the income from self-employment was earned as a notary Verify the situation by: a. Securing a copy of the taxpayer’s license. b. Generally these taxpayers have another source of income or are retired individuals. c. Reduce the Net Income subject to Self-Employment Tax by the Net Income as a Notary Public. d.
